paper_decoration.summary: The surah titles (sûre başlıkları) throughout the manuscript are executed in zerendûd (gold-painted/gold-worked) script within blue-ground cartouches, a characteristically Ottoman Quran convention. The colophon inscription (ketebe kaydı) is likewise zerendûd. The opening double-page spread (ff. 1b–2a) carries a richly illuminated serlevha with polychrome headpieces in lapis blue, red, and gold, featuring geometric-floral interlace with what appears to be a halkâr-type outer gold border. Gold cetvels (jadval) frame the text block throughout. Regular text pages carry gold round verse dividers (durak, گل) and red marginal ʿushr/hizb markers. The paper itself is plain cream — the gold-worked technique is applied specifically to surah title cartouches and the colophon, not distributed across the paper ground as zerefşân.

key_indicators: Dated colophon AH 973 / CE 1565–1566: falls in the late Suleiman / early Selim II period of peak Ottoman court Quran production
Polychrome serlevha headpieces with lapis-blue ground, gold geometric-floral interlace, and pointed-arch form — consistent with nakkaşhâne-i hümâyun Quran production of the 1550s–1570s
Zerendûd surah-title cartouche convention: a well-established Ottoman Quran format associated with court-level manuscript workshops
Mesih Paşa vakıf affiliation: high-level Ottoman patronage context consistent with Istanbul court production
Gold cetvels throughout and gold verse dividers (durak): luxury framing system standard in court-commissioned Qurans
cross_tradition_caveats: No explicit workshop city stated in colophon (colophon page not digitized)
Istanbul attribution is inferred from date, patron status, and stylistic consistency — direct confirmation would require examination of the colophon

limitations: Colophon page (zerendûd ketebe kaydı) not digitized — colophon inscription itself not visually confirmed
Only 3 pages examined; the full extent of zerendûd surah titles across the manuscript not individually checked

elements.description: Gold-worked cartouches at the top of each page containing the Basmala and surah name in gold script on lapis-blue ground. Framed in gold borders. This is the zerendûd technique applied to the 'ʿunwān al-sūra' (surah headpiece).
elements.location: top of each text page, within the serlevha headpiece zone

elements.description: Rectangular headpiece panels with pointed-arch lower profile in deep lapis blue ground decorated with geometric-floral interlace in red, gold, and white. Contains the zerendûd surah title cartouche. Borders in gold and black banding. Classic mid-Ottoman Quran format.
elements.location: top of each opening page (ff. 1b and 2a)

elements.description: Wide decorative gold border framing the full text block on the outer margins of the serlevha pages. Appears to be a halkâr-type or gold-wash outer frame. Adds to the overall luxury presentation of the opening.
Multi-line cedvel system framing the text block with gold ruling lines, clearly visible on both pages of the opening and continuing throughout the manuscript.
elements.location: frame lines around text block throughout

folio_analyses.notes: The double-page serlevha is the most decorated section of the manuscript. The zerendûd surah title cartouches are clearly visible, confirming the catalogue claim 'sure isimleri zerenduddur.' The polychrome headpiece is consistent with Istanbul court Quran production of the 1560s.

folio_analyses.folio: Regular text pages — early quire (IIIF p003)

elements.description: Round gold rosettes used as verse separators (durak / gül) between Quranic verses, visible at regular intervals throughout the text. Executed in gold on plain cream paper.
Red-ink marginal annotations marking the ʿushr (tenth-part) and possibly hizb (half-juzʾ) divisions. Written in the outer margin in red ink alongside the text column.
elements.location: outer margin at regular Quran divisions

elements.description: Gold ruling lines framing the text block, continuous from the serlevha opening.

folio_analyses.notes: Regular text pages show the standard luxury Quran framing: gold verse dividers and red marginal division markers. No margin decoration beyond gold cetvels. Paper is plain cream/off-white with no zerefşân or zerkâri treatment.

folio_analyses.folio: Regular text pages — later quire (IIIF p006)

elements.description: Gold round verse dividers continuing throughout the main text body, consistent with p003.
Arabic numeral/word annotations in red marking Quran reading divisions. The word 'عشر' (ʿashr / tenth) clearly visible in the margin.
Gold ruling lines framing text block, consistent throughout.

folio_analyses.notes: Confirms the pattern established in p003: gold verse dividers and red marginal markers throughout, with plain paper margins. No surah title visible on this spread — the zerendûd surah cartouches would appear at the opening of each surah.

terms_used.english: gold-painted surah headpiece / zerendûd surah title — the surah name written in gold script or applied gold within a coloured cartouche at the start of each Quranic surah; a standard Ottoman luxury Quran convention
gold-painted; gold-applied; lit. 'covered in gold' — applied to text inscriptions, cartouches, and headings rather than paper ground
illuminated headpiece at the top of the text opening
ruling lines framing the text block; gold ruling (altın cedvel) in luxury manuscripts
round gold rosette used to mark the end of individual Quranic verses
gold-worked: motifs worked in gold on paper or other surfaces
Quran manuscript (physical codex of the Quran)
Islamic pious endowment; the act of dedicating a manuscript or property for religious/charitable use

provenance.waqf: Vakfedildi: Mesih Paşa — the manuscript was dedicated as a pious endowment (vakıf) by Mesih Paşa. Mesih Paşa served as Ottoman Grand Vizier briefly under Sultan Bayezid II (r. 1481–1512) and held multiple provincial governorships. He was of Byzantine (Palaiologos family) origin and converted to Islam, rising through the Ottoman devşirme system. His library vakıf at the Süleymaniye complex is now the Mesih Paşa Koleksiyonu. Note: the manuscript is dated AH 973 (1565–66), which postdates Mesih Paşa's death by over 60 years — the vakıf was either constituted posthumously from funds he endowed, or later manuscripts were added to the collection by his successors.
provenance.notes: Cataloguer: Murat Serdar Saykal (YEK record 307588). The date discrepancy between patron death (c. 1501) and manuscript date (1565–66) warrants further archival investigation. Possible explanations: (1) the vakıf endowment was constituted or augmented after Mesih Paşa's death by his heirs or the Süleymaniye foundation; (2) the manuscript entered the collection through later donation attributed to the original vakıf; (3) a different Mesih Paşa or namesake is involved. The colophon (not yet digitized) may clarify.
